name: RiskSense
description: This app integrates with the RiskSense platform to perform investigative and generic actions to detect and monitor vulnerabilities across the entire attack surface, hosts and applications, using RiskSense's inherent intelligence-driven risk analytics to manage and control an organization's cyber risk

actions.verbose:
• The fieldname, operator, value, and exclusivity parameters are used to create a filter. So, the length of these four parameters must be the same.
  • Similarly, a sorting direction is required for a host attribute that is used for sorting. So, the length of sort_by and sort_direction parameters must be the same.

fieldname.description: Host attributes to filter the results (allows comma-separated)

operator.description: Operators to be applied on the provided fieldnames (allows comma-separated)

value.description: Values for the respective fieldnames (allows JSON formatted list)

exclusivity.description: This parameter allows the user to determine whether to fetch the results that are matching the filter criteria (defined by the Fieldname, Operator, and Value parameter) or to fetch the results that are not matching the filter criteria

sort_by.description: Host attributes to sort the results (allows comma-separated)

sort_direction.description: Sort direction values for the respective host attributes in sort by parameter (allows comma-separated)

page.description: Index of the starting page to fetch the results (Default: 0)

max_results.description: Maximum number of hosts to return (Default: 1000)

  • Similarly, a sorting direction is required for an application attribute which is used for sorting. So, the length of sort_by and sort_direction parameters must be the same.

operator.description: Operators to be applied on the provided fieldnames (allows comma-separated)

value.description: Values for the respective fieldnames (allows JSON formatted list)

example_values: Adversaries can exploit unpatched flaws, default accounts, unprotected files, directory listings, etc. to gain access to unauthorized information or to escalate privileges.

Am I Vulnerable To 'Security Misconfiguration'?
Is your application missing the proper security hardening across any part of the application stack? Including:
Is any of your software out of date? This includes the OS, Web/App Server, DBMS, applications, and all code libraries (see new A9).
Are any unnecessary features enabled or installed (e.g., ports, services, pages, accounts, privileges)?
Are default accounts and their passwords still enabled and unchanged?
Does your error handling reveal stack traces or other overly informative error messages to users?
Are the security settings in your development frameworks (e.g., Struts, Spring, ASP.NET) and libraries not set to secure values?
Without a concerted, repeatable application security configuration process, systems are at a higher risk.
Maintain a process for building hardened systems.  Rapidly deploy patches for the framework, operating system, and application software.

How Do I Prevent 'Security Misconfiguration'?
The primary recommendations are to establish all of the following:
A repeatable hardening process that makes it fast and easy to deploy another environment that is properly locked down. Development, QA, and production environments should all be configured identically (with different passwords used in each environment). This process should be automated to minimize the effort required to set up a new secure environment.
A process for keeping abreast of and deploying all new software updates and patches in a timely manner to each deployed environment. This needs to include all code libraries as well (see new A9).
A strong application architecture that provides effective, secure separation between components.
Consider running scans and doing audits periodically to help detect future misconfigurations or missing patches.

Solaris 10 and 11 hosts are vulnerable to a telnet daemon flaw.

The telnet daemon passes switches directly to the login process which looks for a switch that allows root to login to any account without a password. If your telnet daemon is running as root it allows unauthenticated remote logins.

Telnet poses a risk because data transferred between clients may not be encrypted. Telnet is also a frequent target for port scanners.
An attacker can login with any account without a password.

[b]Description: [/b]The remote Windows host is affected by the following vulnerabilities:
	Multiple remote code execution vulnerabilities exist in Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) due to improper handling of certain requests. An unauthenticated, remote attacker can exploit these vulnerabilities, via a specially crafted packet, to execute arbitrary code. (CVE-2017-0143, CVE-2017-0144, CVE-2017-0145, CVE-2017-0146, CVE-2017-0148)
	An information disclosure vulnerability exists in Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) due to improper handling of certain requests. An unauthenticated, remote attacker can exploit this, via a specially crafted packet, to disclose sensitive information. (CVE-2017-0147)


The ShadowBrokers released exploits for these vulnerabilities in 2017 titled EternalBlue, EternalRomance, and EternalSynergy. As a result, this host is critically vulnerable to exploitation. 


[b]Evidence: [/b]The following screenshot exploits an information disclosure vulnerability to determine if the supplied Windows patch is in place.

[image=28523][/image]Detecting vulnerable hosts.

[image=28524][/image]Remotely exploiting a host.

[b]Solution: [/b]Microsoft has released a set of patches for Windows XP, 2003, Vista, 2008, 7, 2008 R2, 2012, 8.1, RT 8.1, 2012 R2, 10, and 2016. RiskSense recommends applying the relevant patch as soon as possible.
These devices are to be decommissioned soon
Detected service telnet and os SOLARIS 9-11

SPARC:
Install patch 120068-03

x86:Install patch 120069-02
A newer patch 125419-01 is also available which obsoletes 120069-02.

Workaround:
To workaround this issue, the telnet service can be disabled as in the following example (Note that this will remove the functionality of the in.telnetd daemon on that host):

# svcadm disable svc:/network/telnet:default

In addition, it is also possible to uncomment (or add) the 'CONSOLE' line in the "/etc/default/login" file so that it looks similar to the following:

CONSOLE=/dev/console

However, this will only prevent unauthorized access to the root account; other user accounts will still be affected by this issue.

Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:

6523815: Solaris (telnetd)

Virtual Patches:
Trend Micro Virtual Patching
Virtual Patch #1000942: Solaris Telnetd User Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
Finding was approved in risk acceptance workflow

[b]Description: [/b]RiskSense achieved Domain Admin level compromise of the internal network from an external, unauthenticated initial position by using a ShellShock vulnerability present on three hosts on the external network to breach the perimeter, then a combination of default credentials and low complexity passwords to elevate to control of the entire internal network.

[b]Evidence: [/b][image=28526][/image]The web interface of an external host vulnerable to shellshock.

[image=28525][/image]Demonstrating command execution using curl. The first command creates a ten second delay because the "openssl" binary is available on the target system. The second command creates no delay because no file named "/usr/bin/fake" exists (as expected). The presence of /usr/bin/openssl is important for further exploitation because openssl can be used to create a "reverse shell".

[image=28533][/image]Deploying an openssl-based reverse shell command. This command initiates an outbound connection to a RiskSense controlled server, then accepts commands from and returns command output to that server.

[image=28436][/image]Recieving the reverse shell connection with metasploit. From the reverse shell it is possible to observe that the captured host has connectivity to the internal network, as demonstrated by a successful ping of a domain controller at 10.6.0.29. The second ping test returns no response, as expected, because no host exists at 10.50.50.50 on the internal network. The output of the "id" command shows that our commands are running as a low-privilege user. This reduces the effectiveness of using this host as an attack platform (notably, we will be unable to perform packet captures and perform most types of broadcast poisoning). Additionally, this host has very limited RAM and disk space, further reducing it's usefulness for further attacks. Nevertheless, this host is able to perform ping scanning, TCP port scanning, and TCP forwarding. These abilities are sufficient to exploit other internal vulnerabilities to gain a stronger internal foothold.

[image=28432][/image]Using the pre-existing "nc" binary from the captured host to expose an internal TCP service to an external attacker. The upper left terminal contains the previously established reverse shell where RiskSense has executed commands to create an "outbound-outbound" connection adapter. The upper right terminal shows commands executed on a RiskSense server to create an "inbound-inbound" connection adapter. The bottom terminal shows the ultimate result of the two adapters: connecting to an internal SSH service from an external host without the use of VPN.

[image=28439][/image]The SSH service exposed in this way allows root access using common credentials admin : admin.

[image=28428][/image]The available memory on the compromised SSH server.

[image=28519][/image]The available disk space on the compromised SSH server. The SSH server had a large amount of available disk space and memory which made it a higher quality choice for launching subsequent attacks than the easily compromisable XS camera devices on the internal network.

[image=28522][/image]The compromised SSH server was operating an SMB server prior to RiskSense accessing the device. RiskSense used Pcredz to log challenge hashes for user accounts as they attempted to log in to this service. Acquiring these challenge hashes allowed RiskSense to perform offline password guessing against the passwords of the user accounts that accessed the service. To increase the number of collected hashes RiskSense used Responder LLMNR and NBT-NS poisoning to redirect connections intended for non-compromised machines towards the compromised host.

[image=28521][/image]Using hashcat to perform offline password guessing. Offline password guessing will succeed against low-entropy passwords and will not succeed against very high entropy passwords. In this case, RiskSense successfully guessed the passwords for the PALTO and CMCLIENT accounts.

[image=28431][/image]Obtaining any valid user account allows an attacker to retrieve a list of all valid domain usernames and view metadata associated with all accounts. Many accounts were identified with passwords stored in the account metadata.

[image=28534][/image]Obtaining any valid user account allows an attacker to enumerate credentials stored in Group Policy Preferences files. The passwords obtained this way were no longer valid for the listed accounts, but were valid for other obtainable usernames including the ".\Administrator" account on multiple hosts. RiskSense achieved Domain Admin compromise using these credentials through several cycles of iteratively spraying credentials using wmiexec, extracting new credentials from captured hosts using mimikatz, and spraying the newly acquired credentials to acquire more hosts.

[image=28535][/image]By repeating the credential spraying process RiskSense acquired a password for the "sqlservices" user from host 10.6.0.30. This user is not a member of the "Domain Admins" group, but has local administrative privileges on a domain controller and therefore was able to extract the central password database for the domain. At the time of the assessment it appears "reversible encryption" was enabled for domain passwords, meaning that RiskSense was able to download passwords for all domain users in plaintext, unhashed form. This could allow an attacker to immediately attempt to use these passwords to log in to external services such as Facebook or Gmail.

[image=28440][/image]RiskSense later identified that the host at 10.6.0.30 is missing critical patch MS17-010 and is susceptible to exploits derived from NSA hacking tools leaked to the public by The ShadowBrokers. This missing patch presents a much shorter path to network-wide compromise available to unskilled attackers using off-the-shelf tools.

[b]Solution: [/b]	Apply software updates to the hosts vulnerable to ShellShock to remediate the ShellShock vulnerability. Restrict access to those hosts from the external network if possible.

	Use network segmentation to minimize the visibility hosts providing external services have into the internal network.

	Change the guessable password on the compromised SSH host to a strong, non-guessable password.

	Remove readable credentials from Group Policy Preferences files.

	Remove user account passwords from LDAP "Comment" fields.

	Apply patch MS17-010 to all hosts vulnerable to MS17-010 exploits.

	Use high complexity passwords for Windows accounts to prevent hashcracking of captured NetNTLM challenge hashes.

	Require SMB Signing or SMB Encryption on all hosts that accept SMB connections to prevent SMB Relay attacks.
External Unauthenticated Domain Compromise via ShellShock

This module exploits the argument injection vulnerability
        in the telnet daemon (in.telnetd) of Solaris 10 and 11.
Sun Solaris Telnet Remote Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
Solaris 10 and Solaris 11 (SolarisExpress) Remote Access Telnet Daemon Flaw

Argument injection vulnerability in the telnet daemon (in.telnetd) in Solaris 10 and 11 (SunOS 5.10 and 5.11) misinterprets certain client "-f" sequences as valid requests for the login program to skip authentication, which allows remote attackers to log into certain accounts, as demonstrated by the bin account.

sound/core/timer.c in the Linux kernel before 4.11.5 is vulnerable to a data race in the ALSA /dev/snd/timer driver resulting in local users being able to read information belonging to other users, i.e., uninitialized memory contents may be disclosed when a read and an ioctl happen at the same time.
Number of host findings: 5, Number of error host findings: 0

Solaris 10 and 11 hosts are vulnerable to a telnet daemon flaw.

The telnet daemon passes switches directly to the login process which looks for a switch that allows root to login to any account without a password. If your telnet daemon is running as root it allows unauthenticated remote logins.

Telnet poses a risk because data transferred between clients may not be encrypted. Telnet is also a frequent target for port scanners.
An attacker can login with any account without a password.
Detected service telnet and os SOLARIS 9-11

SPARC:
Install patch 120068-03

x86:Install patch 120069-02
A newer patch 125419-01 is also available which obsoletes 120069-02.

Workaround:
To workaround this issue, the telnet service can be disabled as in the following example (Note that this will remove the functionality of the in.telnetd daemon on that host):

# svcadm disable svc:/network/telnet:default

In addition, it is also possible to uncomment (or add) the 'CONSOLE' line in the "/etc/default/login" file so that it looks similar to the following:

CONSOLE=/dev/console

However, this will only prevent unauthorized access to the root account; other user accounts will still be affected by this issue.

Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:

6523815: Solaris (telnetd)

Virtual Patches:
Trend Micro Virtual Patching
Virtual Patch #1000942: Solaris Telnetd User Authentication Bypass Vulnerability

A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that the scripting engine handles objects in memory in Internet Explorer, aka 'Scripting Engine Memory Corruption Vulnerability'. This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2020-0673, CVE-2020-0710, CVE-2020-0711, CVE-2020-0712, CVE-2020-0713, CVE-2020-0767.

actions.description: Tag the assets that are fetched using the filter
actions.verbose: • The fieldname, operator, value, and exclusivity parameters are used to create a filter. So, the length of these four parameters must be the same.

tag_name.description: Name of the tag to be associated

entity_type.description: Type of the asset/entity to which the tag will be applied

fieldname.description: Attributes of the asset type to filter the results (allows comma-separated)

operator.description: Operators to be applied on the provided fieldnames (allows comma-separated)

value.description: Values for the respective fieldnames (allows JSON formatted list)

exclusivity.description: This parameter allows the user to determine whether to fetch the results that are matching the filter criteria (defined by the Fieldname, Operator, and Value parameter) or to fetch the results that are not matching the filter criteria

create_new_tag.description: Create a new tag or not if the tag does not exist

tag_type.description: Type of the new tag (required field when Create New Tag is enabled)

tag_description.description: Description of the new tag (required field when Create New Tag is enabled)

tag_owner_id.description: Owner of the new tag (required field when Create New Tag is enabled)

tag_color.description: Color of the new tag (required field when Create New Tag is enabled)

propagate_to_all_findings.description: Detonates if an asset tag should be applied to all its findings (required field when Create New Tag is enabled)
